_header: Conceived man how may that by reason brought about
Subjects: carols, of the Virgin’s motherhood; Incarnation, mystery of
_description: On the mystery of the Incarnation — five quatrains in long lines and two-line burden: ‘Mervell nothyng joseph that mary be with child / She hath conceyved vere god and man and yet she undefiled’

BodLatLitb14.Transcription:
Marvell not Josephthoogh mary be wythe chyldeshe hath concevyde
                    a very maneand yet she not defylde
BodLatLitb14.Note:
Burden only; on a slip of parchment bound between original flyleaf and
                    first folio of a fourteenth-century breviary; formerly part of a
                    pastedown.

BLAdd20059.First Lines:
Conceyved man how may that he be by reason broght abowteBy gode
                    reason aboue all reasons hit may be withouten dowte…
BLAdd20059.Last Lines:
…Then serue the fyrst & save the thyrdde the forte let be
                    resyledAnd mervell no more but fast beleve mary was maide with
                    child
BLAdd20059.Note:
Burden at head of page: ‘Mervell nothyng Joseph thaȝ mary be
                    with child / She hath conceyved very god & man & yet she
                    vndefiled’ (f. 6v). Nineteenth-century transcript by Hunter is
                        London,  British Library Addit. 24542, f. 178.
BLAdd20059.Editions:
Greene,  Richard Leighton. 
             The Early English Carols.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon,
            1977: 185-6; 1977, 164.
